ValueDomain.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Primary Lesion Anatomic Site
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla._A term that refers to a pathologic process in its original anatomic site of growth._Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The superolateral extension of the mammary gland into the axilla that consists of fibroadipose tissue, lymph nodes, and lymphatics.

Concepts.definition: The superolateral extension of the mammary gland into the axilla that consists of fibroadipose tissue, lymph nodes, and lymphatics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The pigmented projection on the surface of the breast. Ducts that conduct milk from the mammary glands to the surface of the breast exit through the nipple. (from MedTerms Medical Dictionary; medterms.com)

Concepts.definition: The pigmented protuberance on the surface of the breast through which milk is drawn from the breast.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quarter of the breast which is inferior and medial.

Concepts.definition: The quarter of the breast which is inferior and medial.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quarter of the breast which is inferior and lateral.

Concepts.definition: The quarter of the breast which is inferior and lateral.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quarter of the breast which is superior and medial.

Concepts.definition: The quarter of the breast which is superior and medial.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quarter of the breast which is superior and lateral.

Concepts.definition: The quarter of the breast which is superior and lateral.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The area of the chest beneath the areola of the nipple._The part of the breast which is in the center.

The part of the breast which is in the center.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Primary Lesion Anatomic Site
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002:No Value Exists:Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
A term that refers to a pathologic process in its original anatomic site of growth.
Named locations of or within the body.
